name: Sulphuricum acidum
Relationship: Complementary: PULS.Compare: ARS.; CALEN.; LED.; SEP.; CALC.
Modalities: Worse: from excess of heat or cold in forenoon and evening
Better: and lying on affected side

Rectum: Rectum feels as if it had a big ball
Diarrhoea, fetid, black, with sour odor of body, and empty faint feeling in abdomen
Eyes: Great chemosis of conjunctiva, with aching and sharp pain
Respiratory: Bronchitis in children with short, teasing cough
Respiration rapid with shooting in cervical muscles and movement of wings of nose; larynx moves up and down violently
Stomach: Coldness of stomach relieved by applied heat
Heartburn; sour eructations; sets teeth on edge
Water causes coldness of stomach; must be mixed with liquors
Head: Compressive pain in side of occiput
Concussion of brain where skin is cold, body bathed in cold sweat
Thrust in right temple as if plug were pressed in
Sensation as if brain was loose in forehead and falling from side to side
Relieved by holding the hands near the head
Right-sided neuralgia; painful shocks; skin feels pinched
Pain of outer parts, as if there were subcutaneous ulceration; painful to touch
Abdomen: Weak feeling, with dragging into the hips and small of back
Feeling as if hernia would protrude, especially left side
Female: Erosion of cervix in the aged; easily bleeding
Acrid, burning leucorrhoea, often of bloody mucus
Skin: Hemorrhage of black blood from all outlets
Bad effects from mechanical injuries, with bruises and livid skin
Carbuncles, boils and other staphylococcic and streptococcic infections
Cicatrices turn red and blue and become painful
Extremities: Cramp-like paralytic contraction in arms, hands; jerking of fingers while writing

details: The debility common to acids shows itself here, especially in the digestive tract, giving a very relaxed feeling in the stomach, with craving for stimulants. TREMOR AND WEAKNESS; everything must be done in a hurry. HOT FLUSHES, followed by perspiration, with trembling. Tendency to gangrene following mechanical injuries. Writer's cramp. Lead poisoning. Gastralgia and hypochlorhydria. Purpura hemorrhagia.
dosage: Sulphuric acid mixed with three parts of alcohol, ten to fifteen drops three times daily for several weeks, has been successfully used to subdue the craving for liquor. For homeopathic purposes second to thirtieth potency.
